Published semi-weekly from October to June by the students of Johns
Hopkins University.
Business communications should be addressed to the BUSINESS MANAGER, JOHN HOPKINS UNIVERSITY; all articles and other communications
should be sent to the MANAGING EDITOR.
Homewood 100

All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

The suggestions on fair play, good sportsmanship and coaching
ethics as broadcasted by the Association of Football Coaches of
America, should most certainly be enthusiastically supported by all
lovers of clean sport. If the suggestions were conscientiously carried
out by all institutions engaged in athletics, amateur sport would receive a wonderful boost.
If Hopkins alone follows the suggestions, a fine example will be
set and a fine name will be established for the university. The mem-

FATTIVIA/
CIGARETTES

bers of our teams have, probably, followed the suggestions more accurately than the rooters. In a wild wave of enthusiasm the average
fan forgets that he is playing the coward when he, in the protection
of the mob, denounces the referee. Fortunately, we have had little

now

of this sort of thing this year. The refereeing in the past few games
has been enough to aggravate the wildest fan yet those who loudly
complained found their efforts of no avail. That grandstand evil is
the greatest of all.

for TWENTY

On the field the most condemnable practice is that of "laying
for a player." Because of a particular player's brilliancy at the game,
efforts are frequently made to render him unfit for play. Actual at-

You always knew
they were better.

tempts are made to disable an opponent, regardless of the permanence of such an injury. Such a practice is certainly less humane
than bull-fighting.
Some teams are particularly noted for their clean sportsmanship,
some for their poor sportsmanship. Some have the reputation of
playing "ringers." The school that can produce a clean, sportsmanlike,
winning team will win the admiration of all.
Hopkins sticks to the suggestions.

How about the Football Player Tackling a
Dummy? Isn't he typical of everything you do
in these four years?
You are the Football Player. The dummy is
every knotty problem you trickle, every effort
to earn your way through, every examination,
every campus activity'.
Tackle the dummy hard, and you'll be ready
for even bigger tests in the game of business or
professional life.
Do not say about this symbol,"How clever",
and let it go at that. It is worth nothing unless
it reminds you to get the spirit of the Tackler
into your work.
By his earnestness he seems to feel the thrill
of combat. With setjaws and muscles tense he
plunges at the dummy. For him it is alive, and
the practice is a means to win the game.
If you intend to help score touchdowns after
college, here is a man to measure up to.

of Laws was conferred by Washington College at the last Commencement upon Professor Ralph

of Classical. History. Dr. Magoffin has become an Associate Editor

will get Fisher's Orchestra for, the

The suggestions on fair play, good sportsmanship and coaching
ethics as broadcasted by the Association of Football Coaches of
America, should most certainly be enthusiastically supported by all
lovers of clean sport. If the suggestions were conscientiously carried
out by all institutions engaged in athletics, amateur sport would receive a wonderful boost.
If Hopkins alone follows the suggestions, a fine example will be
set and a fine name will be established for the university. The mem-

of the mob, denounces the referee. Fortunately, we have had little

now

of this sort of thing this year. The refereeing in the past few games

How about the Football Player Tackling a
Dummy? Isn't he typical of everything you do
in these four years?
You are the Football Player. The dummy is
every knotty problem you trickle, every effort
to earn your way through, every examination,
every campus activity'.
Tackle the dummy hard, and you'll be ready
for even bigger tests in the game of business or
professional life.
Do not say about this symbol,"How clever",
and let it go at that. It is worth nothing unless
it reminds you to get the spirit of the Tackler
into your work.
By his earnestness he seems to feel the thrill
of combat. With setjaws and muscles tense he
plunges at the dummy. For him it is alive, and
the practice is a means to win the game.
If you intend to help score touchdowns after
college, here is a man to measure up to.

The honorary degree of Doctor
of Laws was conferred by Washington College at the last Commencement upon Professor Ralph
V. D. Mag-offin, of the Department
of Classical. History. Dr. Magoffin has become an Associate Editor
of the American Journal of Archaeology.

Electrical Eno-ineering, has been
elected PieSiden't of the ,Maryland

At a recent meeting of the Cotillon Board, it was decided to hold
the first cotillon of the year at the
Maryland Casualty Building-, Friday, December 8, 1922. The Board
will get Fisher's Orchestra for, the
occasion At the dance, silver bar
pins with the :Hopkins seal on them
\yin be Oven out as souvenirs. Tickets are now on sale. The price is

that these will soon be sold.
